sections.purpose: To describe the standard operating procedure for the operation of Liquid Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS) for identification, structural analysis, and quantitative determination of pharmaceutical compounds.
sections.scope: Applicable to LC-MS analysis activities carried out in the Central Instrumentation.
procedure: Verify that nitrogen gas supply for nebulization and desolvation has adequate pressure.
Check that the vacuum system is operational and achieving proper vacuum levels.
Ensure mobile phase solvents are LC-MS grade and properly filtered and degassed.
Power ON the mass spectrometer and allow the vacuum system to stabilize.
Power ON the LC system including pump, autosampler, and column oven.
Initialize the data acquisition software and verify system communication.
Perform mass spectrometer tuning and calibration using calibration solution.
Verify that tuning parameters meet sensitivity and mass accuracy specifications.
Set LC parameters including flow rate, gradient program, and column temperature.
Set MS parameters including ionization mode (ESI/APCI), scan mode, and mass range.
Prime the LC system and equilibrate the column with starting mobile phase composition.
Run a blank injection to check for background interference and contamination.
Inject standard solutions to establish retention times and optimize MS parameters.
Verify system suitability including chromatographic resolution and MS sensitivity.
Inject sample solutions and acquire data in full scan or selected reaction monitoring (SRM) mode.
Monitor chromatogram and mass spectra during acquisition for quality assessment.
After analysis, flush the system with appropriate wash solvents to clean the flow path.
Return the LC system to storage conditions and initiate MS shutdown sequence.
Allow the mass spectrometer to vent properly before complete power off.
Process data for peak integration and compound identification, then save all files with proper labeling.
precautions: Use only LC-MS compatible buffers and additives (volatile buffers like ammonium formate or acetate).
Avoid using non-volatile buffers (phosphate, sulfate) that can contaminate the ion source.
Ensure proper vacuum levels before operating the mass spectrometer.
Never introduce air into the MS system while it is under vacuum.
Filter all samples to prevent particulates from reaching the ion source.
Monitor ion source cleanliness and perform regular cleaning to maintain sensitivity.
Use appropriate ESI needle voltage and avoid electrical discharge.
Wear appropriate PPE including lab coat, gloves, and safety goggles.
Follow proper shutdown procedure to prevent damage to the MS detector.
